image.alt_text: Photo by Eco Trails Kerala in Eco Trails Kerala. May be an image of tree, nature and body of water.
image.caption:
A traditional fisherman in the village canals at Kumarakom (Kerala, India)

There is variety of boats in different shapes and styles have traditionally been used in the backwater areas of Kerala. These boats are the main means of transport of men and materials in the Kerala backwaters since olden days. Fishing is the main income earning way of lake & river side residents. The fisher man’s using small canoe for fishing with the help of net/ fish hook, The traditional fisheries sector has been a livelihood means for many indigenous people over the decades.

image.alt_text: Photo by GB (gi•bi) on February 03, 2022. May be an image of outdoors and tree.
image.caption:
🍃Pachamama. Kawasak Sacha. 🍃
Agua de mi cuerpo, sagrada y siempre cambiante.
Fuego de mi sangre, ardiendo en tu conciencia vibrante. 
Tierra de mi apariencia, creada de tu vientre.
Viento de mi aliento, dador de vida y fuerza.
Yo te honro y te susurro:
Matriz divina,
madre entre las madres,
continúa rodeándonos de tu elixir gratificante,
riega delicadamente nuestros sentidos,
con aromas sublimes e inspiradores colores.
Ave blanca, árbol verde, mar celeste, cántico solemne,
Simplemente resiste,
entre lo inconmensurable y el soberbio artilugio del arrogante.
Algún día seremos merecedores,
de tu misterio y tu poder deslumbrante.

image.alt_text: Photo by Mukani Shop on February 17, 2022. May be an image of one or more people.
image.caption:
Olívia Arévalo Lomas nasceu em Ucayali em fevereiro de 1937, e faleceu em 19 de Abril de 2018. Ela foi uma ativista, líder do povo Shipibo - Konibo, defensora dos direitos culturais e ambientais, artesã e era curandeira. Ela era uma mulher sábia, trabalhou ministrando cerimônias com Ayahuasca no Centro de Medicina Tradicional na Selva Amazônica Peruana até 2011, e depois seguiu trabalhando na sua comunidade de Vitória Graça como artesã e curandeira até o fim de sua vida. Após  muitos anos de trabalho, dedicação e acumulação de conhecimento foi considerada uma curandeira da categoria mais alta em sua comunidade, pois era capaz de acessar outras dimensões da existência e realizar curas complexas, como doenças graves e vícios. No dia 19 de Abril Olívia foi assassinada em sua aldeia.  Ela era uma pessoa muito querida e respeitada, sendo descrita sempre como uma mulher doce, gentil, divertida e amorosa.

image.alt_text: Photo by Yawa Journeys in YawaJourneys. May be an image of child, tree and outdoors.
image.caption:
Mukaveine, pequeno guerreiro da floresta! 

Filho do Cacique Nixiwaka e Putanny, Mukaveine faz parte da nova geração que vem estudando a fundo a cultura e espiritualidade Yawanawa. 

Ao lado dos mais velhos, muitas crianças e jovens vêm se aprofundando nos saberes das plantas, histórias e cantos ancestrais, mantendo a cultura viva, forte e em expansão. 

A geração mais nova Yawanawa tem mostrado como a força e a magia de sua espiritualidade segue firme e em eterno movimento.

Viva cada semente da floresta, que com ares de esperança contribuem para que a espiritualidade e o conhecimento indígena resista!

>>><<< >>><<<

Mukaveine, little warrior of the forest!

Son of Chief Nixiwaka and Putanny, Mukaveine is part of the new generation that has been diving deep in Yawanawa tradition and spirituality. 

Being side by side with the elders, many children and teenagers have been deepening their studies with plants, stories and songs, helping to keep the culture alive and strong. 

The younger generation has been showing how the strength and magic of Yawanawa ancestral knowledge remains solid and growing.

Long live each little seed of the forest, that brings hope and contributes to the resistance of indigenous culture and spirituality!

📸 @camillacoutinhosilva

image.alt_text: Photo by Women Of The White Buffalo on February 12, 2022. May be a black-and-white image of one or more people.
image.caption:
“A lot of people don’t even know we still exist.”

- Delacina Chief Eagle from the feature documentary film Women Of The White Buffalo
 
In order for our planet, and its inhabitants, to heal, we must listen to the wisdom and knowledge that all global Indigenous communities hold. This doesn’t just include their spiritual practices; they have ancestral practices that can help in our collective fight against climate change. For too long, humanity has become fragmented and the division amongst us is only causing more harm. 

Climate change affects us all, so the only way to heal Mother Earth is by uniting, connecting with each other and making sure that our Indigenous sisters and brothers are supported and given a global platform.
 
The Great Plains Action Society is a non-profit organization which, by using the notions of Indigenous sovereignty and traditional ideologies, strive for environmental and social justice which are two issues that cannot be separated. As our climate changes, more people will suffer and their mission is to help prevent the atrocities that are occurring to our earth and the people she nurtures.
 
Please head to their website for more information and find out how you can help! (Link in bio)

@greatplainsactionsociety

image.alt_text: Photo by Family Travel & Togetherness in Chief War Eagle's Grave Historical Marker with @visittheusa, @sierraofficial, @1000hoursoutside, @aspinwall, @womenwhoexplore, @this.is.sioux.city, @explore_sioux_city, @walkingsticksandfireflies, @the_mummyhood, @mumsengageclub, @the.mama.crew, @secretmamasociety, @mixingmamas, and @instaparentssupport. May be an image of one or more people.
image.caption:
Chief War Eagle.

I think I’ve mentioned, big girl has a keen interest in Native American history, and I want to support that. I think it’s really cool that she wants to soak up all this historical information and learn about indigenous cultures.

I’m old enough that when I was a kid, we were mostly taught that the ‘white man conquered’ indigenous peoples, and painted us as the heroes. We really weren’t heroic when it came to how Native Americans were treated…like, at all. I want my kids to know the truth.

I taught the girls about important historical figures during Covid shutdowns, and Chief Joseph was one person I think made a lasting impression on the kids.

It was really cool to visit the Chief War Eagle Monument. He was famous for being a peacemaker. When there was so much bloodshed and bitterness between whites and native Americans, he negotiated and hoped for peace. Now that’s a man worthy of remembering.

Do you teach your kiddos about history? Or do you remember field trips or travel to such cool historical spots as a kid?

image.alt_text: Photo by Dank Precolumbian Memes in Amazon Rainforest. May be an image of text that says 'Getting your food by forcing ants to work for you Amazonian farmers The grasshoppers from A Bug's Life Posted in r/DankPrecolumbianMemes by u/ThesaurusRex84 reddit'.
image.caption:
Title: It's not about food. It's about keeping those acts in line! | Submitted in May 2020 by /u/ThesaurusRex84 

https://redd.it/gcqjln/

Context (from OP):

The northern parts of the Amazon show a peculiar system of self-maintaining raised-field agriculture.

The Amazon has many species of ants and termites that build their hills from dirt and plant debris. This hilling behavior seems to have been manipulated by Araquinoid peoples who built grids of small mounds in flood-prone areas. The floods ensured the insects had only one ideal place to build their nests: the mounds. If one was occupied, they moved on to the next one. The ants would then bring in materials to the mounds, which not only provided structural material that constantly maintained the mound, but also gave a constant supply of nutrients to the well-aerated soil.

Now the farms' human creators are long gone, but the ants and termites are still maintaining the farms despite centuries of rain that would have eroded the fields, just as fertile as the day they were left.

image.alt_text: Photo by Kevin Costner's Legacy®️ on February 10, 2022. May be an image of one or more people, people standing and outdoors.
image.caption:
🆕 Kevin Costner and @44_blue have partnered to develop “Onward,” an anthology docuseries about traditions and rituals in Indigenous communities around the world. 

Each episode of “Onward” focuses on a specific Indigenous community and how their people, land and cultures have endured existential threats such as climate change, commercial development and the pandemic.

The concept for “Onward” is based on @caleglendening documentary short of the same name, which chronicled his time embedded with Kazakh-Mongolia eagle hunters in the remote Altai Mountains of Mongolia.

Glendening writes and directs the series, as well as executive produces alongside Costner, Monitor & Merrimack Pictures @gklutch71
and @gillzmcskilz
Stephanie Noonan Drachkovitch executive produces for 44 Blue, a Red Arrow Studios company. Smriti Mundhra, founder of Meralta Films and creator of “Indian Matchmaking,” will serve as showrunner.

“We hope ‘Onward’ will be an intimate portrait of family and community life that celebrates the diversity of cultures — many of them at risk of extinction — across the world,” said Stephanie Noonan Drachkovitch, co-founder and co-CEO of 44 Blue.

“I’m excited by the opportunity to explore the themes of family, sustainability, culture and community through a global Indigenous lens,” said Mundhra. “Especially in partnership with storytellers who are most closely connected to those worlds.”“‘Onward’ is not only a preservation project, but also a celebration of culture,” added Glendening.

image.alt_text: Photo by Women Of The White Buffalo on February 03, 2022. May be an image of child, standing, road and tree.
image.caption:
“The majority of Indigenous communities today struggle with systemic problems related to poverty and lack of access to healthy food. Grocery stores are few and far between in the isolated Native American reservations, leaving tribes to largely depend on outside sources for food. Additionally, poverty rates are so high that few families can afford healthy food.” (From The Red Road Organisation website)
 
Whilst filming Women Of The White Buffalo, the production crew crossed paths with a Native family walking and hitching rides from their home in Wounded Knee to the Pine Ridge supermarket which is a 17 mile journey. Without a car, they have no other choice because there is no public transport system on the reservation. Not only are grocery stores few and far in between, many of them lack healthy or a wide variety of produce, forcing some families to have to drive up to 3 hours to get to the nearest supermarket. 
 
The Red Road is a non-profit organisation which educates and empowers Native individuals and communities. One of their projects is working with several tribes to build community gardens, which provide access to nutritious food as a better alternative to rural grocery stores or fast food restaurants.
 
Please head to their website to find out more and donate to this organisation which also has educational resources and information on a variety of issues that Native Americans face today. 

(Link in bio☝)
 
@theredroadofficial
 
🌎(Sustainable Development Goals in line with The Red Road: 1. No poverty, 2. End hunger, 3. Good health and well being, 9. Reduced inequalities

✨asking for endorsements
✨asking for my dream book cover
✨asking for folks to share my voice 
✨asking for you to buy my book
.
It’s all been sort of scary and vulnerable and stretchy for my soul. 
.
It’s so much easier to support others!!!
.
Receptivity is good medicine too. 💛
.
At the gentle nudges of a dear friend I went to our local @chaptersnewmarket + asked if my book would be available to all of my local peeps on March 15th. 
.
It wasn’t going to be. 
.
If I hadn’t asked, I wouldn’t have known + all who wanted to get it here would miss out. 
.
Request is now in.  Books will be here. 🙏🏽
.
We walked around and I dreamed about where my book might sit on the shelves. 
.
I can’t wait to see it out in the world! 😍😍
.
Thank you to everyone who has supported this dream.  I could not do it without all of you.  Chi miigwetch - with a heart full of gratitude. (And if you haven’t - I would love to share the medicine with you) ❤️
.
33 more sleeps!!!! 🤩🤩🤩🤩🤩🦅
.

image.alt_text: Photo by Tara Browman 👃 in Xʷməθkʷəy̓əm, Səl̓ilwətaɁɬ, and Sḵwx̱wú7mesh Unceded Territory with @tara_boogie. May be an image of text that says 'STOP CALLING THEM SCHOOLS 7559+'.
image.caption:
TW: Canadian Residential “Schools”

First Nations leaders and politicians called Tuesday a "sombre" day, following the announcement that what are believed to be 54 unmarked graves were found at two former residential school sites around Keeseekoose First Nation in Saskatchewan. 
Victims of the joint efforts of the Canadian government and the Catholic Church to erase indigenous culture. 

Residential “schools” operated in Canada from the 1800’s until the mid ‘90’s, the last residential ‘school’ closed in Canada in 1996!

The state & church-run institutions removed more than 150,000 First Nations, Mètis & Inuit children from their families. 

The impacts of these residential institutions/camps have caused deep and long lasting trauma and harm to the indigenous communities of Canada. 

In 2015 the Truth and Reconciliation commission found the government of Canada guilty of ‘cultural genocide’, however to this day, the government & Catholic Church have failed in many ways to meaningfully repair or compensate the lasting harm. 

As a human, parent & educator I’m am disgusted, heart broken, ashamed of our government and the church. 

I am currently running a sticker fundraiser for the IRSSS (Indian Residential School Survivor Society) with 100% of profits going towards their work to support individuals and families affected by the Canadian Residential system. To date we’ve raised almost $1400!

My heart goes out to the indigenous communities of Turtle Island
🧡🧡🧡
Please follow @wetsuweten_checkpoint

image.alt_text: Photo by 𝔸𝕤𝕤𝕠𝕔𝕚𝕒𝕥𝕚𝕠𝕟 𝕁𝕚𝕓𝕠𝕚𝕒𝕟𝕒 in Amazon Rainforest Brazil with @leo.landon.jiboiana, @association_jiboiana, and @ni_yuxibu_altamira. May be a black-and-white image.
image.caption:
A Pajé, or Onaya in Hatxa Kuin traditional language, isn’t only a healer - what we improperly call chaman in the Occident - in service of his or her community 🌿

A Pajé is a bridge between worlds, between the visible and the invisible, between the material and the spirits that wander in the world. She or he is a library of the Amazon. Through plant medicines, Pajés connect to Nature, speak with it. 

Becoming a Pajé is an immensely difficult path, only reserved for those who can endure the ordeals and the responsibility it engenders. For at least a year, on the spiritual path called Pajélanca, they have to stay alone in the forest, dieting sacred plants like the Muka - the mother of plants for the Huni Kuin people in Brazil. Ancients have stayed more than ten years studying, overcoming their fears and embracing Nature.

We have the uttermost gratitude for these doctors who treat not only the body but also the soul, when done with respect and integrity 🙏🏻

Haux Haux !

✍🏼 : @leo.landon.jiboiana 
📸 : aldeia @ni_yuxibu_altamira - Txana Kixtin

image.alt_text: Photo by Win Win on February 13, 2022. May be an image of outdoors.
image.caption:
FREE SPIRIT
Just because you take away my eyes
does it mean that I can't see?
Just because you lock me in a cage
doesn't mean my mind's not free
My heart is kind and loving 
and it's right where it belongs
I refuse to be less of man
because of those so wrong
I look for answers to guide me
along the path of life
I humbly ask for God's good grace
to free my world from strife
May the heavens open up to shine on me
and show me the right way
May I find the strength to win the fight
when evil comes my way
The spirits of our fathers
passes through my very soul
I build fires just to warm my bones
and keep me from the cold
When the air is taken from my lungs
and it's time for me to die
Please don't mourn o'er my body
for I was never one to cry
Just raise your hands onto the air
offering me to the soft winds
Then think of me as the great oak
where much of life begins
Original poem by Tim Stultz

image.alt_text: Photo by LifeGate in Canada. May be an image of 2 people, outdoors and text that says 'LIFEGATE Editoriale Da vittime a "colpevoli" È in corso in Canada il orocesso contro i difensori del territorio Wet'suwet'en.'.
image.caption:
È iniziato il 14 febbraio il processo nei confronti di un gruppo di difensori dell’ambiente e della Terra della provincia della British Columbia, in Canada. Il processo deriva dai fatti del novembre 2021 quando, per la terza volta in tre anni, la polizia si è presentata con le armi in pugno per procedere allo sgombero del territorio Wet’suwet’en, destinato al passaggio del controverso oleodotto Coastal Gaslink.

La vera e propria operazione militare di tre mesi fa si è conclusa con l’arresto di 39 persone – capi ereditari e anziani Wet’suwet’en ma anche giornalisti – e lo sgombero di un blocco stradale eretto per impedire l’accesso allo Wedzin Kwa (fiume Morice), la principale fonte di acqua pulita e habitat naturale dei salmoni. I capi ereditari Wet’suwet’en, le autorità tradizionali della Nazione prima, non hanno mai dato il consenso al passaggio del Coastal Gaslink sul loro territorio.

Nel 2019 il Comitato delle Nazioni Unite sull’eliminazione della discriminazione razziale aveva detto chiaro e tondo che i lavori del Coastal Gaslink non avrebbero potuto andare avanti senza il consenso libero, preventivo e informato dei Wet’suwet’en e aveva chiesto la cessazione degli sgomberi forzati. Le autorità del British Columbia e quelle federali canadesi hanno ignorato l’avviso. Anzi, ora mandano a processo chi pacificamente chiede il rispetto di quella dichiarazione e, soprattutto, della propria terra.

✍️ Riccardo Noury, @amnestyitalia | L’articolo completo è nel link in bio

image.alt_text: Photo by Deep Forest Foundation on February 21, 2022. May be an image of outdoors and text that says '©The Foundat'.
image.caption:
Amelia Panduro, Shipibo curandera, has dedicated her life to deepening knowledge of plant medicine since the age of 24.  Her compassion and care has touched manythousands of lives as she continues to serve her community and international seekers daily. 
📷 Rich Damaru 
.
.
.
Our project, Deep Forest Foundation, has been supporting indigenous infrastructure projects in the Amazon since 2016. As a model of self sufficiency, we currently are trying to raise funds to purchase clean water well digging equipment and train the indigenous locals on its proper use. This will greatly cut down on their reliance from outside contractors, who risk bringing external infectious disease onto their lands and also tend to charge high prices do to the nature of traveling into the forest. Bless!! Any help is appreciated, even if it’s just sharing this post to your story. Learn more: https://www.deepforestfoundation.com/donate
.
.

image.alt_text: Photo by 𝓛𝓪𝓾𝓻𝓮𝓷 𝓡𝓸𝓰𝓮𝓻𝓼 in Gubbi Gubbi Country with @communityfirstdevelopment. May be an image of text that says 'Today we acknowledge the stolen generations.'.
image.caption:
#Apology10 is about marking the 10th anniversary of the National Apology to the Stolen Generations. The National Apology made in Federal Parliament on 13 February 2008 was a landmark event, as the first formal, national recognition of past atrocities and a first step towards restitution.

It was a significant event for members of the Stolen Generations and their families, the wider Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander community and other Australians. Many Stolen Generations members felt that their pain and suffering was acknowledged and that the nation understood the need to right the wrongs of the past. 

Artwork credit / @communityfirstdevelopment

🍃Pachamama. Kawasak Sacha. 🍃
Agua de mi cuerpo, sagrada y siempre cambiante.
Fuego de mi sangre, ardiendo en tu conciencia vibrante. 
Tierra de mi apariencia, creada de tu vientre.
Viento de mi aliento, dador de vida y fuerza.
Yo te honro y te susurro:
Matriz divina,
madre entre las madres,
continúa rodeándonos de tu elixir gratificante,
riega delicadamente nuestros sentidos,
con aromas sublimes e inspiradores colores.
Ave blanca, árbol verde, mar celeste, cántico solemne,
Simplemente resiste,
entre lo inconmensurable y el soberbio artilugio del arrogante.
Algún día seremos merecedores,
de tu misterio y tu poder deslumbrante.
